d.title: VM/Containers in Proxmox
d.body: I have Proxmox 4.4 running on a machine.  I'm testing using Netdata to monitor the system.  The base of the system is Ubuntu/Debian with KVM/QEMU and a web front-end.   I'm not seeing any graphs for the individual KVM/QEMU machines.  Is there a way to get data per VM?

d.title: Alarm "system.softnet_stat" is very strict.

labels.name: monitoring discussion
labels.description: Contains troubleshooting info for properly generated charts and alarms

d.body:
I find myself in the situation that I get the `system.softnet_stat` alarm most of the time. Here is a reminder what I'm talking about:
![unbenannt](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9931588/19129742/b5b1aff0-8b48-11e6-8fe9-a9a7f1bcc379.PNG)

So at first I thought I might have a serious issue with my server, but after reading the [Red Head guide](https://access.redhat.com/sites/default/files/attachments/20150325_network_performance_tuning.pdf) linked on the dashboard I think the alarm is just "to strict". In the guide on page nine it says:

> This value can be doubled if the 3rd column in `/proc/net/softnet_stat` is increasing, which indicates that the SoftIRQ did not get enough CPU time. Small increments are normal and do not require tuning.

On my two core server `cat /proc/net/softnet_stat` looks like this:

```
000008c5 00000000 00000006 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000
0000acd2 00000000 00000006 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000 00000000
```

Lets take a look at the graph:
![unbenannt1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9931588/19130236/a3c40142-8b4a-11e6-962f-e33b98368fe5.PNG)

Most of the time, the blue `squeezed` line is `0` and I have never seen a dropped package. Lets zoom in a bit:
![unbenannt2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9931588/19130357/1fd3b82c-8b4b-11e6-936a-96b69d1535d2.PNG)

Ah there it is: `squeezed=0,001` :)

Maybe the alarm should only count when the squeezed value is bigger than `1`.

d.title: Very high overhead observed on FreeBSD port of netdata
d.body:
As we get to the final stages of offering netdata as a service option, we have been running it on our build server (Running FreeBSD 11-stable, Dual Xeon E5-2690 3GHz, 64GB of memory, other configuration details on request).

This is the average overhead seen with netdata on top(1):

```
  PID USERNAME    THR PRI NICE   SIZE    RES STATE   C   TIME    WCPU COMMAND
99935 netdata       7  52   19  5360M  5286M pause  17 301:36   6.49% netdata
```

It consistently consumes between 5-8% of the CPU and has over 5GB of resident memory.  It is, in fact, the largest memory hog on the system.  Since this is a build machine that regularly runs many intensive FreeNAS build jobs using the clang compiler, that's actually something of an achievement.

This concerns us that netdata may thus end up being a substantial part of the overheads it is measuring.  Perhaps the FreeBSD port is simply new and green and has not yet been optimized?  Let us know what details we can provide - configuration is stock in almost every regard, the only change being to change the bind to address so that external IPs can access the stats.

d.title: Streaming Issues post Netdata Upgrade(build from source vs prebuilt) + Base image OS changeover

labels.name: no changelog
labels.description: Issues which are not going to be added to changelog

labels.name: cannot reproduce
labels.description: This is to tag issues we weren't able to reproduce the problem and fix it

d.body:
##### Question summary

I run Netdata on an OpenShift project with a multi slave(2 right now) -> master

So I was running on Debian Jessie, **compiling/building from source** for Netdata 1.10.0, never really had flakey connections or issues w streaming. But Now I am running on Alpine Linux and Netdata version **1.18.1 already compiled run(netdata-v1.18.1.gz.run)**  I am seeing a lot more problems.

I checked this thread because this error has posted before it seems:
https://github.com/netdata/netdata/issues/6307

This one above ^ seems to be the the one that hits home most to me. I may revert to building from source(as much as I hate having to do that) to fix the flakey connection error issues.

I also checked these thread too because errors looked similar, but my guid is confirmed unique(so not this, master logs above show the uuids are unique too, also unique hostnames too):
https://github.com/netdata/netdata/issues/4049
https://github.com/netdata/netdata/issues/5014

Relevant Config files for slave nodes:

[slave-netdata.conf.txt](https://github.com/netdata/netdata/files/3857052/slave-netdata.conf.txt)

[slave-netdata-streams.conf.txt](https://github.com/netdata/netdata/files/3857057/slave-netdata-streams.conf.txt)


Relevant Config files for master:

[master-netdata-conf.txt](https://github.com/netdata/netdata/files/3857073/master-netdata-conf.txt)


[master-netdata-stream-conf.txt](https://github.com/netdata/netdata/files/3857075/master-netdata-stream-conf.txt)


Did a netstat on the SLAVE node by port for time_wait wondering if there was anything there with ephemeral port exhaustion playing a role in tcp streaming issues and re-connections but seems fine to me:
```
/ $ netstat -nt | sed -r -n 's/^tcp +[0-9]+ +[0-9]+ [0-9\.]+(:[0-9]+).+TIME_WAIT/\1/p' | sort | uniq -c | sort -n

```

Master node seems fine too:
```
/ $ netstat -nt | sed -r -n 's/^tcp +[0-9]+ +[0-9]+ [0-9\.]+(:[0-9]+).+TIME_WAIT/\1/p' | sort | uniq -c | sort -n
      6 :19999
```

Lastly, here is how I build my final docker image based on that prebuilt binary(for the slave nodes for example):
```
FROM docker.company.com/repo/alpine:3.10

USER root

ENV NETDATA_VERSION=1.18.1

# install required packages
RUN apk add alpine-sdk bash curl zlib-dev util-linux-dev libmnl-dev gcc make git autoconf automake pkgconfig python logrotate

ADD . /gitsources
#Fix /opt/netdata path and logrotate
RUN chmod -R 777 /gitsources \
    && touch /etc/logrotate.d/netdata \
    && chmod 777 /etc/logrotate.d/netdata \
    && mkdir /opt/netdata \
    && chmod -R 777 /opt/netdata \
    && chmod 777 /gitsources/kickstart-static64.sh \
    && chmod 777 /gitsources/netdata-v$NETDATA_VERSION.gz.run

RUN bash /gitsources/kickstart-static64.sh --dont-wait --dont-start-it --no-updates --local-files /gitsources/netdata-v$NETDATA_VERSION.gz.run /gitsources/sha256sums.txt

COPY ./system/netdata.conf /opt/netdata/etc/netdata/netdata.conf
COPY ./conf.d/stream.conf /opt/netdata/etc/netdata/stream.conf
COPY ./conf.d/python.d.conf /opt/netdata/etc/netdata/python.d.conf
COPY ./conf.d/python.d/nginx.conf /opt/netdata/etc/netdata/python.d/nginx.conf
RUN touch /opt/netdata/etc/netdata/.opt-out-from-anonymous-statistics

RUN chmod -R 777 /opt/netdata

WORKDIR /
ENV NETDATA_PORT 19999
EXPOSE 19999 19999/udp 8125 8125/udp

CMD /opt/netdata/bin/netdata -D -p 19999
```

##### OS / Environment
Apline Linux / Docker containers(OpenShift/Kubernetes project). 

##### Component Name
Netdata slave->master stream functionality.

##### Expected results
Stream is healthy with no connectivity and dataflow issues.

d.title: False alarms for Redis and Memcache
d.body:
On some of our hosts we're rarely getting false alarms for Redis and Memcached. Just now I came across a host where Redis server is running but no application is using it. But it is available and is just sitting there being idle.

NetData is reporting that no data was collected for more than 61 seconds. I wonder what's going wrong. Is NetData monitoring if there is some activity with Redis and alerts if there is none or does NetData access Redis itself and reporting a problem if itself can't receive anything?

d.title: Incorrect metrics after update (1.13.0 to 1.17.1)
d.body:
##### Bug report summary
Incorrect metrics after update (1.13 to 1.17)

##### OS / Environment
Master/slave setup on Ubuntu 16.04.

##### Netdata version (ouput of `netdata -V`)
netdata v1.17.1-17-gd5a3e415

##### Component Name
Web interface, graphs

##### Steps To Reproduce
Didn't try (can update other servers and see if this happens again).

##### Expected behavior
Correct metrics.

##### Long description
Hi!
First, thank you for your great product! It really helps monitoring our servers. The fact that it is free immensely matters for small startups like ours.

Until today we had NetData v1.13.0-8-g483cdc9d running on all our Ubuntu 16.04 servers (1 master, many slaves). I started updating to latest 1.17 using script kickstart (curl -Ss -o kickstart-static64.sh https://my-netdata.io/kickstart-static64.sh, then ./kickstart-static64.sh).

Master server was updated without issues (metrics look ok). But metrics for the next machine started to show insane numbers:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13305123/64922049-0268ba80-d7d3-11e9-9db8-e584726520cd.png)

NetData shows regular spikes for CPU which I don't observe in top/htop.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13305123/64922071-75723100-d7d3-11e9-8ce4-b38d62f881ba.png)

Plus I noticed that the time in graphs went off (it shows +1hr 47mins for some reason, though system 'date' command shows correct time).

I saved netdata snapshot and will happily email it if required.

d.title: Netdata slaves dissapear after enabling TLS

labels.name: needs triage
labels.description: Issues which need to be manually labelled

d.body:
Hi,
I have installed netdata with helm chart on kubernetes. 
I have created backend with type graphite to send metrics to influxDB. However, after enabeling TLS, all the slaves are missing from netdata and only master is remaining. Here is my configuration in value.yaml:

```yaml
master:
[web]
          ssl key = /etc/netdata/ssl/key/key.pem
          ssl certificate = /etc/netdata/ssl/cert/cert.pem
          bind to = *=dashboard|registry|badges|management|streaming|netdata.conf^SSL=force
          bind to = *=dashboard|registry|badges|management|streaming|netdata.conf^SSL=force *:20001=dashboard|registry|badges|management|streaming|netdata.conf 
[backend]
          # host tags =
          enabled = yes
          type = graphite
          ssl skip certificate verification = yes
          hostname = netdata-master-0
          destination = tcp:influxdbIP:2003
          update every = 10
          send hosts matching = system. *

slave:
stream:
      enabled: true
      path: /etc/netdata/stream.conf
      data: |
        [stream]
          enabled = yes
          destination = netdata:19999:SSL
          api key = 11111111-2222-3333-4444-555555555555
          ssl skip certificate verification = yes
          timeout seconds = 60
          buffer size bytes = 1048576
          reconnect delay seconds = 5
          initial clock resync iterations = 60

```

Can someone please help me how to get back the slaves on netdata, and send the metrics to influxDB?

Thanks

d.title: This agent was built without the dependencies for Cloud and cannot be claimed

labels.name: no changelog
labels.description: Issues which are not going to be added to changelog

d.body:
If you are seeing the following error message:

> This agent was built without the dependencies for Cloud and cannot be claimed

Please note that specific issues that affect your specifc system:

- [x] macOS (_via [Homebrew](https://brew.sh)_) => https://github.com/netdata/netdata/issues/9061
- [x] Amazon Linux 2 (_on [EC2](https://aws.amazon.com/ec2/)_) => https://github.com/netdata/netdata/issues/9169
- [x] CentOS 6.x => https://github.com/netdata/netdata/issues/9152
- [X] #8966 -> PR #9263  - if netdata installed with `kickstart-static64.sh` then ACLK cannot connect *(certificate verification failure)* on RHEL like OSs
- [ ] FreeBSD => https://github.com/netdata/netdata/issues/9109

@netdata/agent Please add additional issues for other specific systems the ACLK either does not work correctly (_for whatever reason_) or the Netdata installer does not correctly support.

##### Netdata version
v1.26.0-76-g8df7778f

System Overview

##### Steps To Reproduce
1. Install netdata from docker hub's latest image
2. Open Netdata Website

##### Expected behavior
Used RAM should be "total - available", but it's not.

d.title: Recurring segmentation fault
d.body:

I updated Netdata to the newest version yesterday morning, and 30 seconds after launching, it crashes with the error shown below. Going back to 19.0 fixes the issue, but it was also working on whatever the previous version I was running from ~1-2 weeks ago.

I am running via Docker, and controlling my container via systemd.

Working: `netdata v1.19.0`

Unknown

Update to latest version of Netdata on Docker, restart.

d.title: [Bug]: Kernel Oops in BPF netdata_tcp_sendmsg
d.body:
### Bug description

All hosts on our Proxmox cluster run Netdata. Yesterday, we encountered a repeating kernel crash on two nodes, which appear to have been caused by Netdatas eBPF plugin (at least "netdata" appears in the call trace). That crash did not take the host down directly, but caused Ceph to stop answering I/O requests, leading to outages for all services on the host. The hosts also did not reboot cleanly, but required a hard reset.

The traces are all somewhat similar, one example (register values removed):
```
BUG: unable to handle page fault for address: ffffffffff6004ad
#PF: supervisor read access in kernel mode
#PF: error_code(0x0000) - not-present page
PGD cbc215067 P4D cbc215067 PUD cbc217067 PMD cbc219067 PTE 0
Oops: 0000 [#2] SMP NOPTI
CPU: 60 PID: 3174 Comm: msgr-worker-1 Tainted: P      D    O      5.15.12-1-pve #1
Hardware name: Supermicro Super Server/H11DSi-NT, BIOS 1.3 06/25/2019
RIP: 0010:copy_from_kernel_nofault+0xa7/0x100
<snip>
Call Trace:
 <TASK>
 bpf_probe_read_compat+0x64/0x90
 bpf_prog_896bb3a8c2cab17b_netdata_tcp_sendmsg+0xbc/0xb48
 ? __mod_timer+0x271/0x430
 trace_call_bpf+0x9f/0x150
 kretprobe_perf_func+0x4e/0x280
 ? tcp_schedule_loss_probe.part.0+0x13c/0x1a0
 ? tcp_write_xmit+0x98e/0x1480
 kretprobe_dispatcher+0x6c/0x80
 ? inet_sendmsg+0x43/0x70
 __kretprobe_trampoline_handler+0xb3/0xe0
 trampoline_handler+0x48/0x60
 kretprobe_trampoline+0x2a/0x50
RIP: 0010:kretprobe_trampoline+0x0/0x50
<snip>
 sock_sendmsg+0x5e/0x70
 ____sys_sendmsg+0x257/0x2a0
 ? import_iovec+0x31/0x40
 ? sendmsg_copy_msghdr+0x7e/0xa0
 ___sys_sendmsg+0x82/0xc0
 ? bpf_ktime_get_ns+0xe/0x10
 ? __fget_files+0xa3/0xd0
 ? __fget_light+0x32/0x80
 __sys_sendmsg+0x62/0xb0
 ? __secure_computing+0x43/0xe0
 __x64_sys_sendmsg+0x1f/0x30
 do_syscall_64+0x5c/0xc0
 ? irqentry_exit_to_user_mode+0x9/0x20
 ? irqentry_exit+0x19/0x30
 ? common_interrupt+0x55/0xa0
 ? asm_common_interrupt+0x8/0x40
 entry_SYSCALL_64_after_hwframe+0x44/0xae
RIP: 0033:0x7f7c56507e4d
<snip>
 </TASK>
Modules linked in: xt_mac xt_nat xfrm_user overlay binfmt_misc veth rbd ceph libceph fscache netfs ebtable_filter ebtables ip6table_raw ip6t_REJECT nf_reject_ipv6 ip6table_filter ip6_tables iptable_raw ipt_REJECT nf_reject_i>
 zzstd(O) zlua(O) zavl(PO) icp(PO) zcommon(PO) znvpair(PO) spl(O) vhost_net vhost vhost_iotlb tap ib_iser rdma_cm iw_cm ib_cm ib_core iscsi_tcp libiscsi_tcp libiscsi scsi_transport_iscsi drm sunrpc ip_tables x_tables autofs4>
CR2: ffffffffff6004ad
---[ end trace 22a4446218922888 ]---
RIP: 0010:copy_from_kernel_nofault+0xa7/0x100
<snip>
```
The call traces always have `RIP: 0010:copy_from_kernel_nofault+0xa7/0x100`, `bpf_probe_read_compat+0x64/0x90` and `bpf_prog_896bb3a8c2cab17b_netdata_tcp_sendmsg+0xbc/0xde8` at the top, but differ slightly after that. If required, I can post them all in full.

In total, we had six such crashes, which reoccurred after a reboot, until we disabled the ebpf plugin.

The hosts ran kernel `5.15.7-1-pve` or `5.15.12-1-pve`, I think the Proxmox kernels are based on Ubuntu.

### Expected behavior

No kernel oops occurs.

### Steps to reproduce

I'm really not sure if this is reproducible, it happened spontaneously on two of our three hosts. It reoccured every one to two hours, until we disabled the ebpf plugin.

### Installation method

native binary packages (.deb/.rpm)

### System info

